results.title: Italian farm family
results.brief_description: A glimpse of life in Italy during the late sixties in the farming area near Mt. Vesuvius. Shows the day to day life of the Falco family: the sowing and reaping of the crops, bread baking in the home and the many tasks undertaken by various members of the family. Also shown is the community life in the area.

results.title: Italian children
results.brief_description: Depicts activities in the daily life of farm children in the province of Umbria. Portrays features of their home environment such as their house, garden and food, show children participating in the farm work, particularly in the picking and processing of olives. Illustrates the role of family festivities and musical enjoyment in the lives of Italian children, and features market activities in the Italian city of Assissi.

results.title: Italian-Ethiopian war: Africa in world affairs
results.creator_credit: William Kronick, Alan Landsburg Productions, Films Incorporated and Anthony Potter
results.brief_description: Centres on the Italian Ethiopian war of 1935-1936 to lead into an examination of Italian fascism, the character of Mussolini, and how he came to power. Shows how the conflict was one of the chief episodes that paved the way for World War 2. Seen from an essentially American perspective, this film combines contemporaneous actuality footage and interviews with US academics. Written by Anthony Potter. This film is suitable for Upper Secondary levels.

results.title: It wasn't easy
results.creator_credit: Arthur Hammond, ONF | NFB, Nederlandse Omroep Stichting and Nico Crama
results.brief_description: Half a million people of Dutch origin live in Canada. This film looks at the unique character of the Dutch Canadians, their reasons for leaving the Netherlands and their contribution to Canadian society and culture. A cross section of Dutch Canadians living across Canada are interviewed.

results.title: It took a thief to stop a thief
results.creator_credit: Is Your Home Safe Inc, Media Productions, Walter Shaw and Randy Grinter
results.brief_description: This video covers everything from criminal attitude to locks, alarm systems, lighting, windows and position of the house. The video explores ways in which your house can be made more secure. Hosted by Walter Shaw with Eddie Egan.

results.title: It takes a child: Craig Kielburger's story: a journey into child labour
results.creator_credit: Judy Films, TV Ontario, Judy Jackson and Deborah Parks
results.brief_description: Canadian born Craig Kielburger was 12 years-old when child labor activist Iqbal Massih (who was also only 12 years-old) was murdered in Pakistan. That event changed Craig’s life forever. In December 1995 Craig went on a seven week journey to South Asia including India and the Philippines, to see for himself the horrific situation of child labor and children who are sold and traded on the sex tourist market. In India, the number of unemployed adults is 55 million, whilst equally, the number of child workers is 55 million. Children are leased by their parents as collateral for a loan and remain bonded to the factory owners as the debt can never be repaid. As young as 5-year-olds can work upto 12 hours a day with no schooling, barely any food and paid a pittance, if paid at all. They are slave labor working in the most inhumane conditions. What Craig saw and the knowledge he gained turned him into a passionate, articulate and incredibly effective advocate on the children’s behalf. With a group of his peers, Craig founded “Free the Children”, a children’s organization completely run by young people, that now has 10,000 members in 20 countries across the world. This documentary acknowledges Craig’s dedication and testifies to the fact that even children can help bring about change through protest and involvement. Narrated by Jennifer Dale.

results.title: It needs political decisions
results.creator_credit: Vivian Ducat, Film Australia, Chedd-Angier Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This program examines the role that governments can play in protecting the environment. In Zimbabwe, President Mugabe talks about the importance of education and of balancing people’s needs against those of the environment. In Thailand, as in Zimbabwe, population growth has been a major problem, and government birth control programs have played an important role in reducing this growth. Popular protest also plays a role in influencing governments, as in Sweden which now has a nuclear ban forced by the people, but care should also be taken that the political decisions made have taken every possible outcome into consideration. Narrated by Karina Kelly. A teacher’s book accompanies the video.
